segments.text: The three friends enter the room and immediately see Dorian Gray seated at the piano, his back turned as he turns the pages of a volume of Schumann’s 'Forest Scenes.' The atmosphere is charged with quiet expectation.
segments.voice_traits: calm, measured, with a storytelling cadence and subtle pauses to emphasize visual details

segments.text: You must lend me these, Basil. I want to learn them. They are perfectly charming.
segments.voice_traits: clear, expressive with a lively cadence and a hint of theatrical insistence

segments.text: That entirely depends on how you sit to-day, Dorian.
segments.voice_traits: measured, refined with a slight amused lilt and deliberate pacing

segments.text: Oh, I am tired of sitting, and I don’t want a life-sized portrait of myself.
segments.voice_traits: slightly dismissive yet playful, with a quick, light swing in tone

segments.text: I beg your pardon, Basil, but I didn’t know you had anyone with you.
segments.voice_traits: smooth, with a fleeting blush evident in his tone and a tender pause

segments.text: Basil introduces his companion: Lord Henry Wotton, an old Oxford friend whose presence immediately alters the room’s dynamic.
segments.voice_traits: narrative tone that is informative and observant, with a subtle dramatic inflection

segments.text: You have not spoiled my pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray. My aunt has often spoken to me about you. You are one of her favourites, and, I am afraid, one of her victims also.
segments.voice_traits: smooth and urbane with an undercurrent of mischief; measured pace and clear enunciation

segments.text: I am in Lady Agatha’s black books at present. I promised to go to a club in Whitechapel with her last Tuesday, and I really forgot all about it. We were to have played a duet together—three duets, I believe. I don’t know what she will say to me. I am far too frightened to call.
segments.voice_traits: quavering slightly with a touch of humor, deliberate pacing that reveals inner anxiety

segments.text: Oh, I will make your peace with my aunt. She is quite devoted to you. And I don’t think it really matters about your not being there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits down to the piano, she makes quite enough noise for two people.
segments.voice_traits: light, breezy and urbane with a playful inflection and relaxed delivery

segments.text: That is very horrid to her, and not very nice to me.
segments.emotion: laughing, with a tinge of self-mockery
segments.voice_traits: bright and lilting, with a short, amused chuckle embedded in the line

segments.text: The painter Basil Hallward’s eyes wander admiringly over Lord Henry’s youthful, handsome features – scarlet lips, frank blue eyes, and crisp gold hair – qualities that make him immediately trustworthy, almost as if untainted by the world.
segments.voice_traits: richly descriptive with gentle emphasis on visual imagery and an admiring, reflective cadence

segments.text: You are too charming to go in for philanthropy, Mr. Gray—far too charming.
segments.voice_traits: smooth, languid tone with a graceful wave in his cadence that is both persuasive and ironic

segments.text: Basil, busy mixing colours and preparing his brushes, looks troubled. The tension between art and interference is palpable as he glances at Lord Henry and hesitates.
segments.voice_traits: reflective, with subtle pauses that draw attention to the internal conflict of the artist

segments.text: Harry, I want to finish this picture to-day. Would you think it awfully rude of me if I asked you to go away?
segments.voice_traits: firm and deliberate, with an undercurrent of artistic passion and a touch of exasperation

segments.text: Am I to go, Mr. Gray?
segments.voice_traits: light, teasing with a casual drawl that belies his intelligence and charm

segments.text: Oh, please don’t, Lord Henry. I see that Basil is in one of his sulky moods, and I can’t bear him when he sulks. Besides, I want you to tell me why I should not go in for philanthropy.
segments.voice_traits: soft, urgent yet musical, with gentle inflections and a hint of childlike dependency

segments.text: If Dorian wishes it, of course you must stay. Dorian’s whims are laws to everybody, except himself.
segments.emotion: wryly resigned with a hidden affectionate humour
segments.voice_traits: measured, with a reflective tone and slightly ironic cadence

segments.text: You are very pressing, Basil, but I am afraid I must go. I have promised to meet a man at the Orleans. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Come and see me some afternoon in Curzon Street. I am nearly always at home at five o’clock. Write to me when you are coming—I should be sorry to miss you.
segments.voice_traits: smooth, urbane with a confident tone and a measured farewell

segments.text: Basil, if Lord Henry Wotton goes, I shall go too. You never open your lips while you are painting, and it is horribly dull standing on a platform trying to look pleasant. Ask him to stay. I insist upon it.
segments.voice_traits: clear, direct and with a buoyant quality that mixes youthful whimsy with earnest desire

segments.text: Stay, Harry, to oblige Dorian, and to oblige me. It is quite true, I never talk when I am working and never listen either, and it must be dreadfully tedious for my unfortunate sitters. I beg you to stay.
segments.voice_traits: calm yet firm, with a slight exhalation of amusement and a rhythmic, painterly cadence

segments.text: But what about my man at the Orleans?
segments.voice_traits: casual, with a brisk tempo and a playful, arch lilt

segments.text: Sit down again, Harry. And now, Dorian, get up on the platform, and don’t move about too much, or pay any attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a very bad influence over all his friends, with the single exception of myself.
segments.emotion: instructive with a touch of exasperation
segments.voice_traits: authoritative yet amused, with clear annunciation and deliberate phrasing

segments.text: Dorian steps up onto the dais with the air of a young Greek martyr and casts a subtle look of discontent toward Lord Henry—a look that contrasts markedly with Basil’s measured calm.
segments.voice_traits: elegant, with a slow, grand delivery evoking classical imagery and restrained emotion

segments.text: Have you really a very bad influence, Lord Henry? As bad as Basil says?
segments.voice_traits: light and slightly mocking, with a hint of gentle challenge and playful intonation

segments.text: There is no such thing as a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral—from the scientific point of view. To influence a person is to give him one’s own soul. He does not think his natural thoughts or burn with his natural passions. In essence, our aim should be self-development. People are afraid of themselves nowadays; they feed the hungry and clothe the beggar, yet their own souls starve. Courage has fled from our race. Perhaps we never had it at all...
segments.voice_traits: measured, with a slow, hypnotic pace; rich in cadence and heavy with rhetorical pauses that invite introspection

segments.text: Stop! Stop! You bewilder me. I don’t know what to say. There is some answer to you, but I cannot find it. Don’t speak—let me think. Or rather, let me try not to think.
segments.voice_traits: halting, with a tremor of vulnerability and a pause-laden cadence that underscores his inner turmoil

segments.text: For nearly ten minutes Dorian stands in silence, his parted lips and strangely bright eyes betraying a secret turmoil. New, unfamiliar emotions churn within him as music and words stir his soul.
segments.voice_traits: soft, introspective, using long, meditative pauses to reflect the internal transformation

segments.text: Basil, I am tired of standing. I must go out and sit in the garden. The air is stifling here.
segments.voice_traits: brief, clipped with a dry urgency and a slight note of relief at the prospect of fresh air

segments.text: My dear fellow, I am so sorry. When I am painting, I can’t think of anything else. But you never sat better. You were perfectly still, and I have caught the effect I wanted—the half-parted lips and the bright look in the eyes. I don’t know what Harry has been saying to you, but he has certainly given you a most wonderful expression. I suppose he has been paying you compliments. You mustn’t believe a word he says.
segments.voice_traits: soft-spoken with a thoughtful, artistic lilt and a measured pace that reflects his concentration

segments.text: I know you believe it all. I will go out to the garden with you—it is horrifically hot in the studio. Basil, let us have something iced to drink, something with strawberries in it.
segments.voice_traits: light, relaxed with a playful yet cultured timbre and an easy, conversational rhythm

segments.text: Outside in the garden, Dorian is found among great cool lilac blossoms, inhaling their perfume as though it were the finest wine. Lord Henry comes up quietly and places a reassuring hand on his shoulder.
segments.voice_traits: richly visual and sensory, with a gentle, evocative delivery tempo

segments.text: You are quite right to do that. Nothing can cure the soul but the senses, just as nothing can cure the senses but the soul.
segments.voice_traits: smooth, with a warm, mellifluous tone and measured pauses that emphasize every reflective word

segments.text: I believe that if one man were to live his life fully—giving form to every feeling, expression to every thought—the world would be filled with a fresh impulse of joy. Yet the bravest man is afraid of himself. One loses every impulse suppressed and with each passing moment, the beauty of youth wanes, replaced eventually by the decay of time.
segments.emotion: eloquent, persuasive, and tinged with melancholy
segments.voice_traits: resonant, with a rhythmic, almost hypnotic cadence; words are carefully enunciated with lingering inflections and thoughtful pauses

segments.text: How sad it is! I shall grow old, and horrible, and dreadful. But this picture will remain always young—it will never be older than this particular day of June. If only it were I who was to be always young, and the picture that must grow old… For that, I would give everything. Yes, there is nothing in the whole world I would not give—I would give my soul for that!
segments.voice_traits: tremulous and impassioned with a rising pitch of despair; every word is weighted with longing and dread, with heavy pauses that punctuate the confession

segments.text: Basil and Lord Henry exchange looks as Dorian, transfixed by the vision of his own portrait, contemplates the price of beauty and the inevitable decay of time. In a moment of inner turmoil he nearly seizes the palette-knife on the table, as if to destroy the very image that haunts him.
segments.voice_traits: somber, reflective and measured with an undercurrent of tension and soft, pained cries of regret

segments.text: Don’t, Basil, don’t! It would be murder!
segments.voice_traits: sharp, with a trembling urgency and staccato delivery that conveys panic

segments.text: I am glad you appreciate my work at last, Dorian. I never thought you would.
segments.voice_traits: measured, with a cool, detached tone and subtle pauses that echo the finality of his sentiment

segments.text: I adore simple pleasures. They are the last refuge of the complex. But I don’t like scenes—except on the stage. What absurd fellows you are, both of you! Come, Mr. Gray, my hansom is outside. I can drop you at your own place. Good-bye, Basil. It has been a most interesting afternoon.
segments.voice_traits: lively and urbane with a theatrical, almost sing-song rhythm, punctuated by ironic chuckles

segments.text: As the door closes behind them, Basil sinks onto a sofa with a pained expression. Dorian lingers before his portrait—a mirror of eternal youth as his own beauty stands in stark contrast to the future decay he dreads. The day’s revelries and philosophical debates leave him haunted by the fragility of his soul.
segments.voice_traits: soft and reflective, with gradual, fading intonation that leaves the listener in a state of contemplative silence
